Westhampton, July 22 1812
Honored & Respected Sir,
So high an opinion do I entertain of your humanity & politeness, as to persuade myself that you will excuse the liberty I am taking. 
I have been told that it was the intention of the Editors of the Panoplist to publish the journal which I kept in my late tour into Canada. It is with solicitude I request you, my Honoured Sir, if this be the case, to see that the part which respects the meeting & doings of the Protestant association be left out, for this  reason, the meeting was secret; as those who attended did not wish that the design of their coming together should be known to their Brethren, who profess to be Roman Catholics. 
It is my opinion, if it should be published, that it will do more hurt then good; as several copies of the Panoplist go regularly into Canada among the Romish Clergy, through the medium the Rev. Dr. Matignon, or some other person in Boston. 
I have several small religious tracts by me (of my own translation) in the Iroquois language; — and I wish to know by you Sir, whether any of them can be printed at the expence of "the Massachusetts Society for promoting christian knowledge."

Onieda March 28th, 1822.
Honoured & Respected Sir,

Yours of the 23d inst together with a copy of yours to Judge Dean was yesterday received. 
I am truly happy to find, that the letter written by you to Judge Dean has nothing in it which indicates, that money had been drawn as the Chiefs who wrote to you had understood. The letter lay some time in the hands of the Judge and a number of the opposition party saw it and put in circulation stories to the effect stated to you by the friendly Chiefs. 
I hope you will take no exception on account of their writing, as they did it in the simplicity of their hearts. You have long been acquainted with Indians and know something of their late contest, and the tenacity of there opinions. It has been the case for six months past that both parties have been writing to the President, Bishop and Governour — Wherefore, I hope you will not suppose it as a want of respect, especially as the party who lately wrote have stated to me, since the receipt of your Letter, the regret for the misunderstanding, and the highest respect, regard, and veneration for you. 
I am sorry to say that I fear too many people stand ready to write and serve the Indians and fear, when serving them that they often put words in their mouths — whether, they are friendly or not to the Indians, I cannot say. But permit me to remark that I am assured, and

Decision of the Commissioner in the Claim of E. Williams.
The fact of Mr. Williams having acted as the Agent or Delagate of the Oneida, and also that he was one of the principal agent in the nogotiation of the treaties of 1821 & 1822 are fully proved, as well by the admission of the chiefs as by the highest specis of evidence, viz: the treaties themselves and many written memoranda. The chiefs of the one party have, from the beginning opposed this claim, alledging several reason for that opposition, none of which, in the opinion of the commissioner as sufficient to destroy the claim of Mr. Williams: On the other hand, it appears that Mr. Williams has at different times, and when the Oneidas were poor, received from them many evidences of their kindness: It is also clearly proved that the claimant during the time he acted as the Agent of the Oneidas were the sole & regularly appointed deputy of the St. Regis tribe; and Mr. W. will be entitled to a claim for services

Washington April 27th 1858
Dear Sir,
My affairs are now in such a state, that my presence is now no longer necessary here and to avoid further expense, I am desirous to leave the city as soon as it may be. I am now in a debt 70 Dollars for my board and not a Dollar in hand to answer this demand. If you have recovered the sum mentioned in your Letter, may I ask you to send the same to Josiah F. Polk Esq. of this city. 
You did not mentioned the sum or the Bank where the check may be presented. You have I presumed, apprised the Bank of its failure in reaching me — to prevent fraud!
The committee of the house have reported & printed wherein the Secretary of the treasurer is authorized to pay to the Rev. Eleazer Williams the sum of fourteen thousand dollars for services rendered &c. and that the name of said Eleazer Williams be placed upon the pension list as of the date May first 1856, and that he be entitled to receive, during his natural life, the yearly pension of two hundred & nineteen Dollars.
There is a movement & actually in operation in the Indian Committee, which greatly excites my feelings — & in which I am deeply interested — we are soon to be called upon to relinquishe our rights to the land in the Indian Territory, west of Missouri. A certain Mr. Thompson, who had 

Ayer N.A. ms. 1000a
Completed

a management of the Menominies Indians case, which is similar to the New York Indians now in the hands of the Committee, he was allowed forty thousand Dollars. Now my services in the later case is already acknowledged by the Committee and since this the case, it is the utmost importance that I should repair immediately to the New York Indians to receive the sum I am entitled to growing out of those services I rendered to them. I am actually in distress, (as now is the time) for want of money to accomplish this desirable object. Could you not obtain upon loan, one hundred & fifty Dollars for ninety days — and I will give a prime of fifty Dollars for the sum, and I will endeavour to be punctual for the return of the money at the time specified. I hope you will make a great effort in my behalf in this matter — I have every reason to believe that a large sum is now within my reach. — to lay a foundation for this, no time is to be lost. 
Let me hear from you as soon as convenient, and Mr. Polk will expect to hear from you. In great haste
I am dear Sir, yours
respectfully, Eleazer Williams

In the commencement of the year 1818, I could only say that my success had been thus far but partial; and from the course I had taken to disseminate the religious truths among the Oneidas, I was fully persuaded that it was the only mode and I did not doubt it would ultimately be more successful, and therefor must be persevered in.

It was my hope among the other fruits of the spirit, which my friends the Episcopalians might derive from
Completed

my labours would be an increase of a mission spirit among them. For I had ever regarded, that all true and lasting missionary zeal as proceeding from that love to God and love to our neighbor which the Gospel enjoins, and which none but those who have the aid of the Spirit can possess. We can hardly expect to excite an intelligent & effectual interest in the Missions of the Church, unless we keep our people well informed concerning them. To this end, it is believed, that my Diocesan in his annual addresses to the convention, he mentioned of what we were doing at Oneida.
I had still met many discouraging events; but I have also had encouraging evidence of God's favor. This
Completed

or at least to hear from me that glorious Gospel spirit was at first proclaimed in the land of Palistine. This was most gloomy period of my mission. There were six nations of Indians, whose eternal salvation lay near my heart, & who had more than once invited me to visite them that they may hear the Gospel of Christ. & I saw then, that the church I had connected myself with, would not sustain me to the full extent of "my heart desires", so after many days of fasting, humiliation
Completed

prove in the end, a last to me, and this would have been the case had it not been for the friendly interference of Chancellor Kent, Lieut Governour Tayler of Albany, and the Hon's Nathan Williams & Morris S. Miller of Utica.
In consequence of this, my means to sustain myself since I entered into the Oneida Mission, had been very limited. My principal dependence to maintain myself, had been upon $1.25, which the church in the state of New York allowed me.

 My Indian Brethren, saw with their own eyes, I was contented with my humble living and had submitted to many inconveniences that I might be useful or to do them good.
Completed

He was supplied with means which enabled him to maintain three schools in the tribe & for himself with a salary of $500 per. an.

When he first came to us, we hailed him as our friend, our brother, and our guide in spiritual things; and he shall remain in our hearts and minds as long as he shall teach us the ways of the great spirit above.

During the greater part of the winter I have endeavoured faithfully to instruct the Oneidas in the great truths of the Gospel, either in Lectures or in private instructions in their families. I trust my labours have been useful in some measure to them. I feel myself bound, by all the ties, that a complicated scene of unmerited goodness can lay one under, thankfully to adore and praise the god of all grace, for
Completed

brethren, what shall we do to be saved. And we hoped, there were goodly number, who, by the gracious influence of the spirit, were brought to rejoice in the truth, with Joy exceedingly great & full of glory. Well may we rejoice with them, that in the midst of deserved wrath, God remembered mercy for those who were ready to perish.

 We had a strong demonstration, in the midst of the tender solicitude of my Oneida friends, for true salvation of their souls, that although christians may pray for sinners, and the ministers of Christ entreat them, yet they will remain unmoved  The enquiry was often made, "why was this ?" As this caused me so much trouble in my attempts to moderate the excited feelings of the grieved  party, and to remove the jealousies and prejudices of the pagans on account of it. The many & various duties which I had been compelled to perform the year past, have, in a great measure impaired my health; so that about this time, I was scarcely able to go through the services on Sundays. In my communication to the Bishop on the 23d of Nov. I was under the necessity of informing him, that my health was in a feeble state - that I had a turn spitting blood & was grievously troubled with a pain in my breast - In congruence of which my friends were alarmed with my situation, and my attending Physicians

There is evidently a great & important revolution in the state of the Indian population already commenced, and now rapidly gaining forward, affecting immediately the tribes residing in the basons of the several states, and on the frontiers, and which, it is believed will ultimately & speedily be left by those not? the remotest distance. The evidence of this revolution exists in the peculiar interest which is felt and manifested for the general improvement & welfare of Indians, and in the peculiar corresponding feelings & movements among the Indians themselves. The Civil & religious commnties are remarkably awake on this subject,

Some of this is applicable to the case of the Six Nations in the State of New York. They have become sensible that there must be change not only in regard to their present residence, but their civil polity and the manner of obtaining their livehood. They see by the impudence of their former chief & by the intrigues of designing white men, their territories had become so limited & scarcity of timber, as to foresee that it can not be long before they must become in want, of this article, so necessary for their fires, buildings & fences.

The best and most successful means which could be employed by Government & religious societies to civilize the Indians, according to Dr. Maye opinion, was to learn them to cultivate the soil, as the whites do, - they will soon see the advantages of employing the plough, harrow & c. &c. and be indeed to imitate our example, and thus get on the road which leads to civilization before they are aware of it.   In regard to the removal of the New York Indians to the west, it was not new subject to the Oneidas or the other branches of the confiderates, but this had been repeatedly discussed in their general councils since 1812. At that time had a special invitation from western tribes to have their present residence and accept a location which they

I was kindly entertained by the President Monroe & the Secretary of War while in washington & by seasonal members of Congress by whose polite invitation, I was often a guest to their rich tables. Among others, I was noticed by the celebrated John Randolph of Virginia, in whose company I enjoyed much.  As I have met with the Rev. Dr. Morse, so we were together in the several interviews we had with the President & Secretary of War. It was arranged we were to take a exploring tour to the west the ensuing Spring & Summer. A certain number of the Six Nations St. Regis & Stockbridge Indians were to accompany me image of 2 circles with vertical lines through them, and letter P.  I here found that the State of New York was not only interested in the removal of our Indians but there were individuals as well as a company who had a claim to the Seneca

territory west, of a meridian line passing through or near the Seneca lake, & within the present limits of the State of New York. By an amicable adjustment between the two states in the year 1786, Massachusetts released to New York the sovereignty and governmental control over the territory, and New York surrendered to Massachusetts the right of soil, subject to the Indian title, and the right to extinguish the Indian title in her own way. Not many years after this period Massachusetts sold to private individuals her preemption right to the whole country, reserving that power of guardianship over the Indians which the old states have ever exercised within their limits, and which the United States have exercised without the limits of the states and within those limits, where the right of pre emption from the Indians belonged to this government. In this way & for

The Sin forbidden is the worship of God by images, which is the second species of Idolatry, prohibited by the moral law.

 1. The reason of this prohibition is that God cannot be represented by any image, symbol or likeness of any thing wither among the works of nature or art.  He is a spiritual existance & all images are corporeal. They fall infinitely short of any Idea of him. They tend to divess the mind of those conceptions which we ought ever to form of God, as a being uncompounded, indivisible & omnipresent. They are therefore most unworthy of being held forth to the view of the mind as in any measure adequate to God & therefore are impious attempts to bring down the deity to a level with his creatures. God is a spirit infinite & eternal, and images & likenesses are material, corporeal & finite. This preference is every where, but an image is confined to one place, & therefore cannot represent him. No material image can represent a spiritual object, any more than the eye can discern sounds, or the ear colors. Our Lord hath taught us that as God is a spirit, he cannot be worshiped by any resemblances, but must be worshiped in spirit & in truth.
2. No doubt another reason prohibiting the  worship of God by images, is the danger of the mind, payg divine honors to the image, instead of him, whom the image is formed to represent or express. Faithfully discharged from right principles, they are branches of that religion, that is good & acceptable in the sight of God, & which he has graciously promised, he will reward.

 1. The duty of children to their parents is to reverence, esteem & love their persons. They should cherish a cordial regard for them & express it by all suitable words & actions. Even tho' their parents may not be so worthy as others, yet are children bound to show them greater respect than others. This obligation is not destroyed, even tho' the parents one or both should be vicious & profane. They are the authors under God of their existance. Had it not been for them, they would not have been. Their training up in life has also been owing to the labor & care of their parents. Thus filial reverence & respect is due, even to vicious parents & Hill mac? to the worthy & virtuous, because from the latter children have received many more kindness & favors & their gratitude is in proportion to the favors recd from them.
 Children when young, before they arrive to years of discretion, are under the absolute rule & government of their parents, & bound to obey them in all things, not sinful or immoral; and after they have attained to years of discretion & in a capacity to provide for themselves in the World, they are bound to respect & reverence, their parents

We are to preserve the lives of our fellow men by doing nothing that tends to injure their health, or their peace, or worldly estate, and by pursuing such friendly and benevolent means as tend to guard and defend them from injuries and wrong?; administer.g of comfort to the afflicted - clothing to the naked - food to the famishing, nourishment and medicine to the sick and help to the helpless, of all ages and conditions. The duty of preserv.g the life of others appears from several considerations as 1 man is made for society. It is not good for man to be alone. If it was lawful for one one man to take the life of another for any or every cause, a general and universal massacre would take place, for the right of one so to do would be the right of all: and the world would be a slaughter house of desolation, an accldmna?, a field of blood, a golgotha a place of skulls. It is evident that mankind being placed together on the earth, are intended by their creator to be mutually helpful and beneficial to each other. We therefore find that we are mutually dependent on each other; help and society for our comfortable existance here, against the many accidents and evils of life. The helpless infant or the parent the sick, the decripid and aged on those who have health and ability to relieve them. We are not only mutually dependent for our security and comfort as to our animal life, but are dependent on each other under providence, for that council, light and direction that are necessary for the good and happyness of our spiritual Na

resignation of Isaac. He voluntarily submitted to be slain. While Abraham drew the knife to plunge it into the bowels of his beloved Son, he loved him as his own soul & no doubt would most willingly have died in his stead. That Isaac was most freely cont.g as is evident from the circumstances of his age & strength, also was able to carry up upon the Mountain, wood sufficient to continue a sacrifice & Abraham being aged & they two alone, he could have been no doubt easily resisted by his son. This is a most marvellous instance of faith & submission to God, both in the father & the son on sacred record. The most high giving to them thereby a lively representation, of the father offering up his J X well beloved son, our Saviour as a sacrifice for the Sins of the World, when he commanded his sword, to awake against the man of his right hand: & the Son freely offered himself to die for us. In this type Abraham represents, God the father, & Isaac, the Son, our Lord J.X.  Isaac in consent.g to have his life taken away, did it in Obedience to God; & Abraham in consent.g, so far from any murderous intention was influenced by the purest principles of obedience to God whose right to command any actions no creature can dispute, & at the same time activated by the tenderest love to his only Son. God is the absolute proprietor of the lives of his creatures & may consistantly with his goodness & justice make us of one take away the life of another, as he uses any natural means or second causes, to bring to a period our lives.

The same means that are lawfully used to preserve our own lives we are to use to preserve the lives of others. This duty is founded on that second command of the Law, which comprizes all the duties and obligations of the second table & enforced by X's example & command thou shalt love they neighbor as thyself. The same kind of love that we bear to ourselves, when we defend ourselves from injuries - when we shun things hurtful and dangerous to life, when we use means to preserve and save life, are we by this law to use toward our fellow men. And also the same kind of love that we have to ourselves in pursuing & securing our spiritual & immortal interests, are we also to put  in exercise to save the souls of our fellow men, & be mutually promoters of each others eternal life.  H.B. Brevoort Agt of Indian Affairs, James Duane Doly one of the Judges of the Territory of Michigan - Sq. Polier - John Law - Robert Irvin? - 

J.A. Lockwood - Geo Johnston - Agt Grignon - Lamont Fily - Lewis Rouse - Ebenz. Childs, Paul Grignon - L. Grignon -

 Territory of Michigan

Personally appeared before me the subscriber Paul Grignon who being duly sworn despsited and saith that he was present at the time the Treaty or arrangement was held and entered into at Green Bay in August 1821 between Menominies and Winebago Nations and the New York Indians and that he is a native of Green Bay and is well acquainted with the Chiefs and head men of the Menomenie Nation, and that none of the Head Chiefs or principal men of the nation were present at this Council, but that the council was held with several men of little consideration in the nation: that the chiefs and principal men were then absent: that the brother of one of the chiefs come into the council and stated that he was sent by the chiefs of the nation to say that they had no land to dispose of: that they could not part with their lands, or they were already too small and that they were obliged to go on the lands of the neighboring tribes to hunt, and further deponent said not. -

 Sworn and subscribed to before me at Green Bay this 16th day of June 1824
 (Signed)  Paul Grignon

(Signed) Sq. Polier -

boundaries of which they know nothing about. - That the only men of this Nation, who have any rights to the Country claimed by the Nation, which extends from Lake Michigan to the upper part of the Wisconsin River, now sign this paper; not one of whom was present at that treaty; and that as soon as their backs was turned, Some of their men, who had no right to dispose of the land, held the treaty, and whatever consideration was then paid or has since been paid, they know not, having received no portion of the same. That whatever might have been done on that occasion by the Winnebago's, they know not, as they neither speak nor understand their language. - And is an evidence of the fact that they know nothing of that treaty, not one of the old inhabitants of this place was called upon as is usual, to attend at the making of the same - and they are not accustomed to transact so important a business as this would have been without asking their advice -

 They state the same objections to the second or last treaty, which is said to have been held, and their object now is, to, and they do protest against any further settlements being made upon their lands by the Nan-to-ways - "If any more shouts? come here, what shall we do with our wives and children whom we can now scarcely support? We beg of our Great Father to prevent any more of them from coming to this country. - With the Winnebago's we are united by Kindred yet it is with great difficulty that we can live upon terms of Friendship even with them -
 We are satisfied with the settlement made here by the whites, but we cannot admit any nation of Indians to settle in this country.' -

Oneida,  August 4. 1819.

Dear Sir.

 I am favoured with an opportunity to send you a line, hope if you do not come here you will write me a letter by the be?es? of this. I left Randolph about two months ago. I am now living with my brother in Westmoreland. If I conclude to live abant here I shall wish you to live with me if you have been a good scholar & behave well.  I am anxious to hear from you & to know how much you have learned since I saw you. I hope you can now read the Bible & write pretty well. I hope you love to pray and attend meeting on the Sabbath. You must not forget what you learned in Vermont. Remember what my Father said to you about religion. Remember that you must die and go into the world of spirits & you will be happy or miserable, according as your conduct here.
 My best wishes attend you
        your sincere friend

Mr John Alexander   Grand? Bassett
Completed

Ottawa  March 21 1846

Dear John/

 I write to let you know where I am so that if you should happen to be near here you might give me a call. I have heard you speak several times of going to St Louis if you should happen to go you will come here there are Steam Boats every day from St Louis to within 8 miles of here, the river is too low at present for them to come up to this place. The fare is only $5 to St Louis.
  I hope every thing has gone on well with you since I left & that your Mother & all are well -
 When I see you again I hope to be in better Circumstances than when I left the territory - I shall always remember with gratitude the kindness I received from yourself & Mother - The Winter has been very mild & pleasant where I have been - I stayed 2 months in Chicago & did very well there & am now doing very well here in the Store of Messrs Armours of this place for the last 3 months today - they are Scotch & very fine men. Illinois agrees remarkably well with me  I enjoy the very best of health I have gained in weight 12 lbs in the last 3 months -. This is a beautiful little town the Scenery all round for Miles is really beautiful. The Illinois & flox Rivers as well as the Canal runs through here. The Messrs Armours are very large Contractors for the work on the Canal.

Respected Madam,
It appears that my former communication has been received & read with such pleasure & gratification as to produce from your Ladyship of many thanks to the writer as well as many entreaties to have him continue of giving you of some historical facts of his life to this period & to continue the same, till Death shall snatch your Ladyship or him from this pilgrimage state.

  If, Madam, I could with propriety
Completed

   During the winder 1803 _ I went to school as usual, & latter of which I was so unhappy as to be attacked with a slight fever and which continued upon me several weeks,

and after it left me I remained for several months in feeble state, but thro the Kindness of providence, I was finally restored to my strength & health, but not to that degree as
I was before taken with it. One great cause, I presume, prevented of my complete recovery, the deep distress I suffered in mind, On the account of the Death of my
two Sisters & a brother. Not having a sufficient faith in the mercy of God, who doth not willingly afflict, nor grieve the children of men, to submit cheerfully the dealings of his
providence.

Now we have made diligent enquiries about the occupancy and improvement of said lands (situated on Fox River at or near a place called "L̲i̲t̲t̲l̲e̲ ̲K̲a̲k̲a̲l̲i̲n̲)̲ and can find no one to say that P̲i̲e̲r̲r̲e̲ ̲C̲a̲r̲b̲o̲n̲e̲a̲u̲,̲ or any other person but Indians ever occupied or improved said place, till long since 1812. And we have enquired of said Francis St. Roque who is an unlettered and plain Canadian and he most solemnly avows, that he did not know that he had given any testimony touching the improvement of any lands at L̲i̲t̲t̲l̲e̲ ̲K̲a̲k̲a̲l̲i̲n̲ 0r C̲a̲c̲a̲l̲i̲n̲, but, that he supposed his testimony related entirely to a place, six miles lower on Fox River, occupied by said Carboneau._ And we ^have^ the Testimony ^of^ our brethren the Menominies, who have planted & raised corn on the pace "time out of mind" that it has never been occupied by any other than themselves till some years since the late war, since which it was cultivated a year or two by one Reaum, by a permission of the Menominies and of the Indian Agent Col. Bowyer, but has now come into their hands again._ We hope your Honorable Body will not confirm this to any one but upon the best grounds as it will be a great damage to us, by introducing a white family among us us, with its ever attending, and to us destructive vice, the vending of s̲p̲i̲r̲i̲t̲u̲o̲u̲s̲ ̲l̲i̲q̲u̲o̲r̲s!
We know not what other testimony, Mr. Johnson
